interlinear-text.item: Pakhalina, T.N. 1975. Vakhanskii iazyk. Moscow: Nauka. p.136-143. Translated and analyzed by Kevin Sun.
Glossed by Kevin Sun & Daniel Barry

phrase.item: There was a rich man.
This rich man had a lot of wealth.
A rich merchant had a daughter.
The rich man wooed the daughter of the merchant
He spent a lot of wealth, and married the daughter of the merchant.
He lived many years.
And then an end came to his wealth.
Then the rich man said, "Wife, everything that we had is gone, we no longer have any means to survive.
How are we to be?
Let's do this: I'll go to some city and come up with something, I hope that I will be able to make two coins out of one.
I will bring all of this,
check translation
and we will have something to live on."
The wife said: "Good, go and get all the money there is from your treasury, and go!"
The rich man went into his treasury, and there were three thousand rupees there.
He took the three thousand rupees, and went on his way.
He went, and found himself in sone remote, deserted valley, where there wasn't even a trace of a person.
He became very sad and thought: "Here I am in this deserted valley, where there is nobody who could talk with me, so that we could shorten the trip through this valley without notcing."
He looked back, and some person is approaching from behind.
He became very happy: "I looked for and couldn't find anyone to talk to and entertain myself with, and it turns out a person has revealed himself."
They greeted each other, and went on.

On the road the man riding in front asked the other: "You happen to be my travel companion in this unpopulated valley, so tell me some story, so that we can ride out of this valley without noticing because of conversation.
He said: "I don't know anything."
The former exclaimed: "How is it so, that you know nothing?!"
Then he said: "Why do you need me to tell you some story?"
The former said: "I need you to tell me a story so that with conversation we can exit the valley quicker
Then he said: "I have one word, it costs 1000 rupees.
If you have 1000 rupees, I will tell you this word."
He thought: "What is it that he'll say, that costs 1000 rupees?
He had 3000 rupees
"All right, so much of my wealth has gone away, what can I do, so I'll just give him 1000 rupees and hear what he says."
Right away he opened his travel bag, got out 1000 rupees, and gave them to him.
He said: "Remember, if you happen to be in a dry canyon on a rainy day, don't stay overnight."
He said this and became silent
The rich man asked: "Well keep talking friend!"
He said: Well you know I had just one word, and I told it to you, and now again if you have 1000 rupees, then I'll tell you another."
The rich man thought: "What kind of word is this, that he takes 1000 rupees from me for?'
And said: "Fine, what can one do?"
He got out 1000 rupees, and handed them over.
He took them and said: "If you acquire wealth, then don't show anyone that which is most valuable in it!"
And there he fell silent
Then he asked him again: "Well keep talking, friend!"
He said: "I know nothing more, if you need me to tell you something, then I have one word worth 1000 rupees."
The rich man thought again: "He took these two thousand rupees from me, and from what he said noting became clear. Fine, now I'll give him these last two 1000 rupees that I have left.
He got it out and handed it over to him.
He took this also
The rich man said: "Now that you've taken the money, tell me!"
That man said: "I'll tell you this: don't tell your wife what's on your mind!"
Having said that, he hurried from his horse.
And told him to hurry as well.
Then he said: "You had 3000 rupees."
I took them from you,
And I told you three things
Now I told you that if it happens to you that you find yourself in a dry canyon on a rainy day, don't stay overnight- remember that!

And I told you: "If you acquire wealth, and something within it is particularly valuable, then don't tell (anyone) about it", so if you follow my advice, keep it a secret, and when you feel like talking about it and find yourself in a tight spot, then ask your mother for advice!

And finally I told you not to tell your wife about what's on your mind, otherwise it will bring you unhapiness; and if it happens that you do tell (her), then, if you touch anything with your hand it will be the end of you."
Having said this, he departed.
He went by one road, and the other - by another.
He went, and day became night.
The sun set, the weather turned back, it started to rain.
He went down from the high place, and saw a caravan of merchants approaching, who settled at the entrance to a canyon.
The rain poured so much that the merchants didn't have time to get their packages off the horses.
The horse with their packages wandered off in all directions
The merchants somehow managed to set a fire.
They boiled themselves some tea.
He approached the caravanchiks and said: "Since you're stopping here, caravanchiks, I'll stay here with you too, I'm alone.
They say: "Okay".
He hurriedly joined them.
He made himself tea.
Then he remembered: "That person told me that if it ever happens, not to stay overnight on a rainy day in a dry canyon. It's raining. I won't stay here!"
He got up and left.
He got out of the canyon, and settled himself there.
That night there was a big flood.
The whole caravan drowned.
All the horses, with their baggage, crowded onto one rock.
The people died.
When morning came, the man saw that the canyon was filled with rocks from the flood, all the people were dead, and all the horses with their baggage were standing on one of the rocks.
The man went down and saw that the people were gone, went and took all the horses with their baggage, and went on.
He brought everything over, untied the packages, and looked inside - there was something extraordinary.
There was a knife there, such a knife that one cannot find in any kingdom.
He didn't hide the knife, but tied it in a visible place on his belt and went hunting in the mountains of Qof.
He hunted for a long time and suddenly came upon an apple-tree there.
There were such apples on it that one cannot find in any country.
He picked the apples and went home.
Two of those apples he gave to his wife.
The wife had a lover.
The wife didn't eat the apples, but hid them.
One day the wife's lover came.
The wife got the apples and brought them over.
The friend asked her: "Where did you get these apples from?"
She said: "These apples, my husband brought them from beyond the mountains of Qof and gave them to me, but I didn't eat them and hid them for you.
Now eat them!"
He said: "No."
A while later he went off to the mountains of Qof to search for that apple-tree.
He found it. He dug it up. He uprooted it.
He leveled the area. He went down and went back.
He went into his lover's house, and she brought the apples again.
She put them in front of him. And her husband was there too.
The wife's acquaintance asked: "From where did you get these apples, rich man?"
He said: "I brought them from beyonf the mountains of Qof."
The friend said: "Don't lie, such apples are not found in any country, how did you suddenly find these apples beyond the mountains of Qof?"
He said: "I did find them."
He said: "Don't deceive me, tell the truth!"
He said: "I'm not deceiving you, I'm telling the truth."
If you don't believe me, lets make a bet.

All right, when we both come to the Qof mountains, if you find this apple-tree, then all my property which your hand touches will be yours, and if you don't find it, then everything of yours that my hand touches will be mine.
They went to the Qof mountains, went up, wandered around, searched and found nothing.
The husband was surprised: "But I found the apple-tree in these very Qof mountains, and now it's gone!"
check "gɨtətɨw"
He returned very sad: "Here I've made a bet with that man, and now he'll take something away from me. I'll go not, take all my property to the bazaar, and sell it."
He went, and took everything that he had to the bazaar.
check "wadʒ"
That man already had revealed his intention to take his wife.
He brought out his wife - and his house had a high roof - and sat his wife on that roof.
Then he called the man with whom he made the bet: "Now come, indicate with your finger everything that you like!"
That man approached, put both hands in his pockets, looked around, and saw the wife sitting on the roof.
He had already seen from far off that the rich man's wife was sitting high on the roof.
And the rich man brought out all the property that he had, put it out in the open, thinking: "He'll come, and let him take everything he likes."
The man came, and didn't look at anything, but made straight for the roof.
On the wall there had been placed a high ladder.
He went toward the ladder, and started climbing it.
He made it halfway, and he got dizzy.
Then he took his hands out of his pockets, and grabbed a step of the ladder.
The rich man jumped up and ran over: 'All this wealth turned out to be unnecessary for you, all you needed was this beam!"
The other man didn't agree.
Then the rich man pulled him down off the ladder.
Suddenly there appeared a judge.
They both went toward the judge, and the husband said: "We had these conditions:
I put out all of my property and brought him under
But he didn't touch any of it, he only touched this stick.
Our conditions were met by this.
So the other man was left with this stick.
